awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Development of Unique Flavor Peptide Ingredients to Create Authentic, Sustainable, and Cost-effective Plant-based Food Products
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will create new meat alternatives.  This project advances a process to create animal-free products with the same authentic taste and textures as real meat. The project will develop four different chemicals for producing various meat flavor profiles, and especially in fat systems, and a novel advanced method for the first true authentic beef flavor profile for plant-based food applications.  This will lower the risk and industry costs for new and diverse alternative meatless food products. 

The proposed project offers a new strategy to address the limitations of existing flavor profiles currently lacking in the plant-based food market by unlocking the power of precision fermentation and peptide encapsulation. Technical challenges include characterizing the unknown “meaty” kokumi peptides properties and identifying the encapsulation parameters necessary for stable capture of both encapsulated umami (BMP) and kokumi peptides. The proposed R&D will (1) generate an advanced encapsulation protocol to capture peptides to produce unique flavor profiles not found in plant-based foods, (2) define the physical and chemical properties of the encapsulated peptides to determine their validity and stability in various food media, and (3) develop first true authentic beef flavor profile for plant-based foods. Research objectives include: (1) formulate and characterize the BMP and kokumi peptides, (2) measure the chemical stability of the encapsulated BMP and four kokumi peptides, (3) measure the encapsulated BMP and kokumi authentic meaty flavor profile in broth and French fry model systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Based in Raleigh, North Carolina, Ummino (formerly Botany AI) is pursuing research and development that is at the forefront of innovation in novel ingredients to help facilitate and support shifting the American diet towards healthier, yet delicious, plant based (PB) foods, from snacks to whole meals.  Building on the technical accomplishments of the company?s research and development efforts, Ummino used funding from Phase I SBIR grant, to develop production and delivery methods of a flavor enhancing product (FEP) which ultimately demonstrated sensory potentiation, strongly enhancing positive consumer perception of PB foods. Where the initial goal of the Phase I project carried out by Ummino was to test the effectiveness of a novel FEP in specifically enhancing the beefy taste and savor profile of PB food analogs, further exploration and discovery revealed the FEP?s unexpected positive impact on potentiating salt, sugar, and, most importantly, mouthfeel of dairy and dairy alternative foods, shifting the team?s focus to developing the FEP?s duration, authenticity, and richness enhancing potential of umami flavors in dairy and dairy-alternative food products. The most significant outcome of this research is the ability for the FEP to deliver a final product composition?s reduction of salt, sugar, and fat without sacrificing a rich consumer experience for favorite dairy-based American foods.

The expansion of our FEP sensory insights appears to converge nicely with the timing of the recently released updated FDA guidelines and corresponding discussion around what ?healthy food" means for American diets, coming at a critical point when the food industry is going through unprecedented transition. PB foods now exist across 30 categories in grocery stores, showing growth across the board. No other food sector has gone through a more significant shift to PB sourcing than the dairy industry. Plant-based milk now soundly occupies 16% of all retail milk dollar sales and this shift has laid the groundwork for major growth of other PB dairy products, which reached $2.1 billion in total sales in 2021. Across the store, PB dairy dollar sales are growing faster than those of many conventional products.

The goal of the Phase I project was to establish a proof-of-concept for the authentic beef flavor profile using Ummino?s signature umami FEP. Ummino explored and tested a range of critical parameters to develop an advanced method that combines the signature umami FEP with a unique, protective delivery system (PDS) to accentuate the duration, authenticity, and richness of umami flavors in PB food products.

The major objectives included, 1. To formulate and characterize the FEP in a PDS. 2.  Measure the chemical stability of the FEP. 3. Measure the FEP?s umami flavor profile in a PDS in model food systems and determine their taste benefits in PB products.

The rationale for this research was based on the empirical observation that PB food products often lack flavor impact (e.g., umami) and often are off-flavored tasting, much like the plants from which they were extracted. Multiple research groups are working on improving extraction and concentration techniques to improve PB protein flavor, but these products will continue to lack flavor molecules encrypted in animal-origin products that stimulate the animal-similar sensory response on the human tongue when they are encountered. This phase of the project needed background information on the FEP in relation to physical properties, as well as confirmation of whether the FEP would elicit an umami response when consumed in common foods. Ummino worked with the North Carolina Food Innovation Laboratory (NCFIL), the leading cGMP pilot plant accelerating PB food research, ideation, development, and commercialization, to study FEP physical properties in aqueous or buffered systems, and then to further study the FEP in model food systems. Ultimately, from an eventual commercialization perspective, Ummino has, from a proof-of-concept perspective, encoded the FEP into a microbe, and then, using a process known as precision fermentation, demonstrated production, recovery, and purification of this FEP.

In summary, Ummino has successfully analyzed characteristics as outlined in the project proposal and, through our work, developed a plant based cream cheese which was used for sensory studies and confirmation of our product?s ability to improve mouthfeel to simulate richness in dairy analogs, enabling reduced-fat products to deliver full taste. Furthermore, the flavor enhancing product?s effectiveness in reducing sodium and sugar can enable a solution to improve the nutritional profile of this category, creating a 'platform' for healthier, improved dairy analogs.


Last Modified: 11/17/2022
Modified by: Christopher Guske

Image
